availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: So Long!
bibl.orgName: Papers of Walt Whitman (MSS 3829), Clifton Waller Barrett Library of American Literature, Albert H. Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

lg.l:
To conclude—I announce what comes
after me,

The thought
rolls through me, filling
must be promulged
me full, that all I know at
any time suffices for that
time only,
and is not enough for the subsequent
not subsequent time

I announce greater days, songs, per‑
sons— orators, bards— and then depart.

I remember I said
at the winter‑close,
at the winter‑close,
before my leaves sprang, that
when I began singing that
before my leaves sprang,
I
would become a candid and un‑
loosed summer poe
m
t
,

del.l:
I said I would not forget you or
The States,

lg.l:
I said I would raise my voice
jocund and strong, with reference
to consummations.—
O when America does what was promised,

When each part is peopled with free
people,

When there is no city on earth to lead
my city, the city of young men,
the Mannahatta city—but when
the Mannahatta leads all the cities
of the earth,

When there are plentiful athletic poems,
Southern and Northern,

When through These States walk a
hundred millions of the most superb
persons,

When all parts away for superb persons,
and contributes to them,

When fathers, firm, unconstrained, nonchal‑
ant, open‑eyed—When breeds of
the most perfect mothers denote
America,
Then to me ripeness and conclusion.

O not me, after all! Rest not with
me!

I seek a man better than I am, or
a woman better than I am,

I invite defiance, and to make myself
superseded,

All I have done I give to be trodden
underfoot, to be the soil of su‑
perior poems.—
I have established nothing for good,

I have but established these things,
till things further onward shall
be prepared to be established,

And I am myself the preparer of
things further onward.—
I have illuminated myself for your sake,

I have
reached
offered
my
myself
hand
love
hand
myself
to every one—I
have journeyed with confident step,

While my pleasure is yet at the full,
I whisper So Long and
kiss
press
take
the
young womans
on the lips
hand
and
the young man's
on the lips,
hand,
for
the last time.—

Once more I enforce you to give play
to yourself, and not depend on me,
or on any one but yourself,

Once more I proclaim the whole of
America for each individual,
without exception.

As I have announced myself on
immortality, the body, procreation,
hauteur, prudence—As I joined
the stern crowd that still confronts
the President with menacing weapons
—I adhere to all;

As I have announced each age for
itself, this moment I set the
example.—

I demand the edifices of the govern‑
ment, to destroy them;

Room! Room! for new far‑planning
draughtsmen and engineers!

Clear that rubbish from the building‑
spots and the paths!
I announce natural persons to arise;
I announce Justice triumphant;

I announce uncompromising liberty
and equality;

I announce the justification of candor
and the justification of pride;

I announce adhesiveness‑I say it shall be —limitless, unloosened,
love and that whereever you are,

( I say you shall yet find the friend you was
looking for—)

del.l: O

lg.l:
Yet, old throat
,
!
,
O yet
one loud
one
a
cadenza ! to show
what we are—now

Now for your own sake,—
for the past, and for
the future

O old throat! what have we
? you
been? What are
we
? you
? What
will be?—I do not

del.l: I
Have you

lg.l:
Come! before we escape,
let us one cadenza for your
own sake, for the past,
and for the future!
O thicker and faster!
O crowding too close upon me!

I foresee too much—It means
more than I thought,—a

A strange something settles
through me—it unties
me and disjoints me,
It seems to me I am dying.—

I announce the continued union of
The States,

I announce splendors and majesties
to make all the previous poli‑
tics of the earth insignificant.

I announce a man or woman coming
—perhaps you are the one,

I announce a great individual, fluid
as nature strong in life, chaste fully
armed, affectionate compassionate, as
death.
fate.—
fully armed.—
? altogether ? contended.—

I announce a life that shall be
free
open,
bold, copious, vehement resolute, spiritual, bold.

And I announce an old age that shall
lightly and joyfully meet
death
? decease
its fate
end.—
O thicker and faster!

O
Now
O
coming
crowding
too
fast
close
upon me!

I foresee too much—it means more than
I thought—a strange
loosening settles
seperating
disjointing
through
disjoins
disjoins
settles through
me—it seems to me I
am dying.—

del.l: O my old firm throat! One firm

Yet One wild
firm
loud
cadenza, still to myself
looking back, with firm throat something firm
Then to pass, to escape.—

lg.l:
old throat! cadenza for me—what I
have been, am, will be,
Then to pass, to escape.—
O thicker and faster! I am crowded too close!
O crowding too close upon me!

I foresee too much—It means more
than I thought,

del.l:
A strange something settles through
me—it unties me and disjoints me,

lg.l:
It
seems
appears
to me I am dying.
Now old throat sound your last!

Salute me, —Salute the future once more!
Salute
Peal
the
future
wild
free
old
cry once more!

Screaming electric, through the
air
atmosphere
surpassing
using,

At
once
random
appearing
glancing
, each as I
pass
notice
pass
saluting
absorbing
,
Swiftly on, but a little while alighting,
Curious enveloped messages delivering,

Sparkles hot, seed ethereal, down in the
dirt dropping,

Myself
Your
Myself
unknowing,
my
your my
commission obey‑
ing, to question it never daring,

To the next age, to many ages, the growth
of the seed leaving,

To troops out of
me
you me
rising,—they the
tasks
I
me I
have set promulging,

To women certain whispers of myself
bequeathing—their affection me more
clearly explaining,

So I pass—a little time vocal,
visible, contrary—afterward a
melodious echo, passionately
bent for, undying,

The best of me then when no more
visible—For it is toward that
of myself when no more visible
I
am
have been
was
incessantly preparing.—

I foresee—I peal one loud cry of
triumph,
? With my own voice I announce myself ?

O brief! O secret minute
moment of us two. O secret
and sudden

O us two only—O secret
and sudden—impromptu
and secret!

Enough
are

the moment
moment
abrupt
impromptu

a

on

acrid and

I take the immeasurable
stride of

What Is there aught more that I lag and
pause?
Is there a dearer single final farewell?

The echoes and songs have subsided ceased ——I advance
out of these—it is very
still,

Somebody's breath is close beside me—
Somebody's heart beats against the
tympans of my ears,

I feel myself fully repaid enfolded—O this is enough
exquisite! O brief! exquisite—O enough!

del.l: All have withdrawn, and I withdraw

lg.l:
Dear friend, whoever you are here,
take this kiss—I give it es‑
pecially to you,

Do not forget me—I must depart—
remember my words,

del.l:
I am as one who has done with
materials,

lg.l:
I am as one disembodied, triumphant
dead.—

del.l:
The echoes and songs entirely cease
—I advance out of them— entirely abandon them— it is
very still,

Somebody's breath close beside falls like dew around me—
Somebody's heart beats the tympans
of my ears,

I feel myself infolded from head to
foot—fully repaid,—delicious

O it This is exquisite! delicious!
O, this, this is enough!

add.l:
The echoes and My songs cease—I entirely
abandon them—it is very still

Somebody's breath falls like dew
around me—Somebody's pulse
beats the tympans of my ears,

I feel myself enfolded from head to
foot—fully repaid—delicious,

Enough, O contact
deed abrupt and secret!

Enough O fastened and loosened
contact!
Enough O impromptu and gliding present!

Dear friend, whoever you are, here,
take this kiss—I give it
especially to you

del.l:
Do not forget me—I must de‑
part—I feel like one who
has done his work

Remember my words—I love
you,—but I launch myself I go progress
off from you
duly further on——I expire
from materials, for reason,

I am as one disembodied, tri‑
umphant, dead.—

add.l:
What is there more that I lag and pause?
That I crouch extended with unshut mouth?
Is there a single final farewell?

transpose.l: *(Is it right? Are we here alone?)
It is I you hold, and who hold you,

add.l:
From behind the screen where
I lay hid I advance per‑
sonally.—
Who touches this touches a man,

*I spring from the pages—decease
calls me forth,

del.l:
Birth, life, the interview, the
quick separation,

Such, and my rounds for many
a year through the States,

Do not forget me—I feel like
one who has done his work,
—I progress on.

Remember my words—I love you—
I expire
depart from materials,

I am as one disembodied,
triumphant, dead.—

lg.l:
Dear friend, whoever you are, here!
take this kiss,—I give it especially to you,

Do not forget me—I must depart—
I feel as one who has done his work,

I am as one disentangled
he who is disembodied triumphant, dead.

What Is there anything aught more, that I lag
and pause?
Is there a dearer final farewell?

The echoes have altogether subsided—
it is very still,

I hear someone breathing Somebody's breath I hear is close beside
me—I hear a beating heart, somebody's heart beats at the tympans of my ears,

I feel myself enfolded—O this is ex‑
quisite!—O us two only!

O us two only! All else has divided fallen
from behind us, and left us, O brief! !

All the rest have withdrawn—but and

add.l: I am as one who has done with materials,

lg.l:
I am as one disembodied, triumphant,
dead.—
Somebody's fingers hand thrill thrills me,

I feel enfolded from head to foot—
fully repaid—delicious,—enough.

del.l: O this, this is enough!

lg.l: O how your fingers drowse me!

Your breath falls around me like
dew,

Your pulse lulls the tympans
of my ears,

I feel immerged from head to
foot,
Delicious—Enough.—
Enough, O deed impromptu and secret!

del.l: Enough, O fastened and loosened contact!

lg.l:
Enough, O gliding present! Enough,
O summed‑up past!

Dear friend, whoever you are, here,
take this kiss—I give it es‑
pecially to you,

Do not forget me—I feel like one
who has done his work—I I progress on,
progress on,

add.l:
The unknown sphere, more real than I dreamed,
more direct, darts awakening rays around me
and about me,—I progress on

lg.l:
Remember my words—I love you—
I depart from materials

I am as one disembodied, trium‑
phant, dead.—
